title: Segments Home Dashboard Tiles
body:
This was the implementation done for segments in the home dashboard tiles. We tested it and it worked fine please verify the flow if this is right.

  1. When we call create tile API there is a middleware attachSegmentsSettings attached to the route which grabs headers from the API and populates the below fields -

    1. targetSegmentId - x-smtip-segment-id

    2. userSegmentId - x-smtip-user-segment-id

    3. isSegmentsEnabled - This is fetched through Harness FF segments_v1

    4. defaultSegmentId - Fetched from segmentsSettingsModel in Content DB

    5. homeDashboardSetting - Fetched from segmentsSettingsModel in Content DB

    6. homeDashboardDefaultSetting - Fetched from segmentsSettingsModel in Content DB

  2. Using the helper function getSegmentIdForHomeDashboard we populate the segmentId variable with targetSegmentId or userSegmentId if the segment is enabled using FF.

  3. This Segment ID is also stored in the DB in the tiles table in the segment_id column if not exist it would be null.

  4. If the API request body has pushToAllHomeDashboards = true this will send a Kafka message with the category PUSH_TILE_TO_ALL_USERS_HOME and the tile record with segment id in the record.

  5. In the function processsPushTilesForUsersBatch, if the message payload has segment_id, it will add segment_id to the where condition or will be null and this is where the query is done over the identity service user DB via Internal API.

  6. Once the users are fetched using batches the tiles will be created for the users.

title: Enterprise search ingestion pipeline optimization
body:
Problem statement : On every bulk sync embeddings are generated every time for all the documents which will increase resource utilization and redundant operations which can impact the costing factor.

Proposed solutions :

  1. Create chunks and embeddings only for the documents which are updated from last sync else skip other, to follow this approach every connectors delta APIs need to be verify.

  2. TBD

Other Scenarios :

There may be a scenario in which we are changing underlying mechanisms for chunking or embedding generation, in this case complete scan will be require, to handle different use cases in different ways application level logic should be in place to check which type of full sync we are running so that application scan documents accordingly.

TBD

title: Advanced JS (TBC)
body:
What is the difference between call, apply, and bind methods in JavaScript?

  • call:

    • Invokes a function with a specified this context and arguments.

    • Example: func.call(thisArg, arg1, arg2, ...)

  • apply:

    • Similar to call, but arguments are passed as an array.

    • Example: func.apply(thisArg, [arg1, arg2, ...])

  • bind:

    • Returns a new function with a specified this context and optional arguments.

    • Example: const boundFunc = func.bind(thisArg, arg1, arg2, ...)

autocomplete: Steps to Hit Cyclr Execute Method API Locally
title: Steps to Hit Cyclr Execute Method API Locally
body:
1. Create a Public & Private Key Pair.

  2. Provide the Public Key to DevOps in order to whitelist your machine in order to be able to tunnel to Bastion locally.

  3. Tunnel to Bastion locally using the following command —

    1. ssh -D 8080 -i id_rsa ec2-user@10.1.0.211

      1. id_rsa — Private Key File Name (run the command in the folder where the Private Key is present)

  4. Install the "http-proxy-to-socks" NPM package globally.

    1. npm install -g http-proxy-to-socks

  5. Run the following command to create an HTTP proxy for your local 8080 port —

    1. hpts -s localhost:8080 -p 8123

  6. In Postman, click on the Gear icon in the top-right → Settings → Proxy → Proxy configurations for sending requests.

    1. Uncheck the checkbox for "Use the system proxy".

    2. Check the checkbox for "Add a custom proxy configuration".

      1. Proxy Type - both ‘HTTP’ & ‘HTTPS’

      2. Proxy Server - 127.0.0.1, 8123

      3. Proxy Auth - Off

  7. Your Public IP address will now be 18.237.61.202

  8. Hit the Cyclr Execute Method API.

title: Reminders
body:
The logic to send out participation windows should be based on how many weekdays are left in the participation window.

  • Participation window: 0-3 weekdays in the participation window (not the length of the PW itself)

    • then don't send a reminder

  • Participation window: 4-9 weekdays in the participation window (not the length of the PW itself)

    • Reminder: 2 weekdays before the survey closes

  • Participation window: 10+ weekdays in the participation window (not the length of the PW itself)

    • First reminder: 5 weekdays after the survey is sent

    • Final reminder: 2 weekdays before the survey closes

title: New features
body:
Following are features implemented in QA-Bot V2 CLI:

  • No need to deal with platform handler API codes
  • No need to directly interface with core-engine
  • Minimum requirement to do formatting for response receive from core-engine
  • Does not directly affect with platform handler enhancement
  • Able to complete test cycle faster (at least 50% faster compared to QA-Bot V1)
  • Minimum configuration required (mostly automated)
  • Manual test on platform handler can be run concurrently (has its own environment)

title: Overview of Architecture
body:
Overview

In version 1, QA-Bot V1 is basically act as a platform handler and talk to Socrates Bot directly . It has some significant impact to cope with actual platform handler enhancement or bug fixes. Speed to complete each cycle of QA test baseline is quite moderate although not slow.

So in version 2, QA-Bot V2 has plug out the platform handler code. It does not interact directly with Socrates Bot, instead it only interact with platform handler and let the platform handler to interact with Socrates Bot. This enhancement has benefited in twofold

  1. Platform handler enhancement does not affect QA-Bot V2 (only send http request or socket to platform handler). No need to enhance code to cope with platform handler.
  2. The speed to complete each cycle of QA test baseline has improved by at least 50%.


Channels supported

  • QA-Bot Console Channel
  • QA-Bot Web Channel
  • QA-Bot Facebook Channel (removed)
  • QA-Bot SBO Channel (removed)
  • QA-Bot Slack Channel
  • QA-Bot Sms Twilio Channel
  • QA-Bot MsTeams Channel

title: What is QA-Bot
body:
1. QA-Bot is a compliance test tool use by QA team
  2. QA-Bot help to achieve following:
    1. To ensure quality of content in source file
    2. To automate test process
    3. To reduce time to do regression testing
    4. Regression test result will be automatically saved in a flat file
    5. Enable to test all channels more efficiently
    6. Reduce human error
    7. QA will be able to repeat regression test frequently

title: How To Install (IVP)
body:
i) create new directory

$ mkdir IVP

ii) give permission

$ chmod -R 775 IVP

iii) copy install.sh file to new directory

$ cp install.sh IVP

iv) copy basecksum.txt file to new directory

$ cp basecksum.txt IVP

v) copy tarball file to new directory

$ cp republic-qabot-ivp_20190109.tar.gz IVP

vi) go to new directory

$ cd IVP

vii) give write permission to install.log

$ chmod 777 .

viii) give executable permission to install.sh

$ chmod 755 install.sh

ix) run installation

$ ./install.sh republic-qabot-ivp_20190109.tar.gz | tee install.log


NOTE:

  • tarball file will usually come in this format (client name)-qabot-ivp_yyyymmdd.tar.gz e.g republic-qabot-ivp_20190109.tar.gz
  • the terminal will prompt you for "app" or "db" - please choose according to the server you are setting up
  • if "db" server is selected, basically it will only perform DB verifcation, no actual installation will be made
  • if "app" server is selected, it will perform APP verification and actual installation
  • npm modules (node_modules) are pack together, it is not being install like other QA-Bot installation

title: Server hardening
body:
Best practice methods for server hardening.

  1. Deployment/Upgrade should be done using the Socrates user only, with the defined Jenkins deployment process.

  2. Any server SSH should be behind the Bastion host (jump host) or Secure Bastion host for preproduction and production

  3. Block SSH from outside except bastion host.

  4. Other than system users, only ansible and Socrates user should have "NOPASSWORD" in /etc/sudoers "ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL"

  5. For the production server, only operations team members should have access.

  6. Server monitoring will be put in place for basic and system-specific requirements and tracked via the server inventory sheet.

  7. Disable remote root login on SSH

  8. Follow the server naming conventions as per Naming Conventions

  9. Securing the ports via AWS security groups based on the environments like (QA, ENG, PRE, PROD...)

Bastion Host-Specific Hardening:

  1. Bastion hosts must use MFA for authentication either using Google Authenticator or Okta MFA via BeyondTrust

  2. Enable Fail2Ban on Bastion hosts and lock the user if more than 5/10 failed attempts.

Other considerations:

  1. Any production or preproduction change should go through RFC (change management) tickets.

title: Perception | Harness flag management
body:
This document covers how we support the Perception dashboard enablement with multiple versions of the Salesforce package and switching between the two dashboard versions.

As of now, there are two versions of the dashboard

  1. dashboard_perception_analytics

  2. dashboard_perception_analytics_v1

Since the salesforce release goes out in the form of a package we do have to design the system to be backward compatible. We agreed upon keeping both flags in the Harness.

Below are the two Harness flags for perception

  1. de_analytics_perception_v1_dashboard

  2. de_analytics_perception_dashboard

Below are steps to manage the harness flag to switch between the new and old versions of the perception dashboard.

  • Salesforce org up to 23.11v → de_analytics_perception_v1_dashboard

  • Salesforce org on or above 23.12v → de_analytics_perception_dashboard

Notes:

To enable the old dashboard on demo org, use the following configuration

Upto 23.11 -> de_analytics_perception_v1_dashboard -> default(false) -> DE(true)
23.12 -> de_analytics_perception_dashboard -> default(true) -> DE(false)

title: Lambda functions
body:
• Different type of branches

    • master (Production)

    • staging,

    • development

  • Developer create a Jira ticket branch from development branch using following naming convention

    • feature/SV2-00000-some-feature

    • bugfix/SV2-00000-some-bugfix

    • hotfix/SV2-00000-some-hotfix

Once the code is merged in development branch, it will be deploy to latest version and can tested in dev env.  If developer is confident then raise PR from development branch to staging branch. This time a new version will be created and will deploy to staging alias. If ticket is closed by QA then the newest version will be point to production alias.

Hot fix branch can created from production branch and once the ticket is closed it can be merged into development and staging branch.

title: Admin: Docusign - schedulerhourlysimpplrservices process
body:
Docusign has run into issues with the bandwidth that the “schedulerhourlysimpplrservices” scheduler is taking in their instance, which is shared with their Salesforce CRM and many other apps.  They have been manually running the scheduler and we’ve agreed to take that on.  In addition they've requested that Simpplr complete this activity and run the scheduler early every weekday morning at 4 AM PST. 

  1. Log into the Simpplr Integration account through support access for Docusign

  2. Under Manage App —> Setup —> Schedulers run the “Schedulerhourlysimpplrservices” scheduler until the job completes.

  3. Once complete, stop the scheduler so it doesn't recur automatically.

That is the extent of the activity. Simpplr performs this activity M-F excluding US holidays and weekends.

title: Team Dumbledore - Definition of Ready
body:
1. Designs and story description should always be in sync - so that issues during implementation do not arise

  2. Acceptance criteria is clearly defined along with the design aspects. If existing design is updated, it should be part of the story.

  3. Mocks / Designs, third party libraries, if any, documentation etc should be clearly specified

  4. Stories should be clear and concise - follow INVEST criteria. Break down stories in case stories are large

  5. Provide Estimations as close to actuals - would need continuous improvement

  6. Stories are provided with estimates and story points

  7. All edge cases are covered

  8. Have system design discussions during grooming sessions

  9. A POC, if needed, should be done prior to creating a story

title: Team Elite - Working Agreement
body:
1. Schedule meetings with details of agenda

  2. Active participation from every team member in grooming sessions

  3. Code reviews to be done on time

  4. Prefer team channel communication if possible / Responding to queries over Slack

  5. Regular time logging and moving assigned task status appropriately

  6. Ask for help when in need / Raise the flag if required

  7. Good communication within the team

  8. Ready to support each other at all times

  9. Tasks to be equally divided among team members

  10. Regularly attend team meetings and inform in advance if not available

  11. Completing assigned tasks within a Sprint

title: Team Elite - Definition of Ready
body:
1. Stories should have proper description, Acceptance criteria and Test scenarios

  2. Provide links to recordings of grooming sessions in the story - helps for referencing later

  3. Context should be clear - as to why we are doing a story / improvement

  4. Single source of truth - All the required information on a ticket (sometimes in the Comments section) should be part of the story description

  5. For CS issues, steps to reproduce the issue should be made available - as far as possible

  6. Design related changes should be explicitly mentioned in the stories

  7. Make available any reference documents / videos of old tickets which explains the functionality or steps to replicate - if possible

  8. Stories should be small enough to be picked up and completed in a Sprint - if they are large (more than 8 story points) should be broken down into smaller stories

title: Team Bigfoot - Working Agreement
body:
1. Meetings should be time boxed

  2. Every one should participate and communicate

title: Translation Process
body:
1. We start work on a new release of our product and all new strings are added to the master version branch

  2. We continue development over a few months and as time progresses we keep adding new strings to the master branch.

  3. When we're happy with the release we ask BabbleOn to do the translations, all in the master branch

  4. When that release finally goes live we make a version branch and copy all the translations from master into it - this is our snapshot in time for that release. We avoid making any translation/string changes in these snapshot version branches, because of the nature of the bug fixes we do it would only ever be a few words anyway and wouldn't be cost effective to translate.

  5. Work on the next new release continues in master, we start again at point 1.

autocomplete: Custom Content Tile on Home/Site Dashboard
title: Custom Content Tile on Home/Site Dashboard
body:
Custom content tile allows a user to create a tile with content selected from multiple sites.

Questions and Answers:

  • When an app manager adds this tile to all users' home, are we going to filter and show user specific content?

    • Yes. An app manager can create a tile by selecting pages/albums/events from multiple sites. However, when tile is rendered to a specific user, we’ll only show the content that the user is allowed to look at.

  • Can a site admin/manager create a tile by selecting content from other sites?

    • Yes. A site manager/admin can create a tile by selecting the content from other sites that they have access to

  • Which service will provide an API to search for custom content?

    • Global Search Service. There is an existing API that we’ll use

    • User will only be able to search for content that he/she has access to

title: Dependabot chores
body:
Steps when dealing with PR opened by dependabot:

  • If any tests failing, close the PR

  • If conflicts, merge from develop and get the CI to run again

  • Check the list of changes that dependabot puts in the PR and make sure there are no breaking changes (most libraries are good with semantic versioning, but not all)

  • if all tests are passing, check the changes for any issues eg things that you expect may be risky. If you are fairly confident then approve, merge the PR (for dependabot PRs we have agreed that's ok) and post in #listener-suite channel that you did that

title: Elastic Beanstalk
body:
The product built during Phase 1 is monolithic and hence, our hands are tied in terms of dividing the existing solution into multiple microservices. Our biggest challenge for deployment is the lack of ability to package the complete code as one package since the deployment process involves cloning multiple Git repos, installing dependencies for each of individual repos, auto-installing servers to run the service and moving the libraries around among repos and central python library folder.

So, Elastic Beanstalk based deployment is ruled out since deploying a decentralized code has its challenges.

title: Audience Table
body:
Proposed Schema:

Create new table audiences

id // auto incremented
audience_id //uuid
created_by  //uuid
modified_by  //uuid
is_deleted //for maintaining deleted audience (soft delete flag)
name // trimmed value of display_name, convert to lower case [Added to maintain unique constraint]
display_name // user input for audience name
audience_type // enum [people/demographic_wise]
audience_rule //jsonb
audience_member_count // stores active member count for that audience

 

audience_rule
Case 1: Demographic Type
{"city":["Y"], "state":["HQ", "GGN"], {"division":["Finance"]}}

Case 2: People type
{"peopleId":["3278e63287648237648732","32678364726123"]} //array of userids

Data sanity to be done before making an insert in the table for this field.

Where clause made by iterating over this object to calculate the audience members.

audience_member_count

Case 1:
Calculate audience count at runtime for each audience and push in the response payload.
Worst-case running 16 different queries in parallel for the demographic case and building response object[Performance bottleneck]
Case 2: [Using this approach]
Maintaining audience_member_count flag in the table. This needs to be kept in sync for all possible user changes[insert/delete/update] & incrementing/decrementing this count accordingly.

 

currently_active

To display: 2 subscriptions, 3 alerts etc in UI

Case 1:
Maintain this data in DB
Default {“subscriptions”: 0, “alerts”: 0, “newsletter”: 0} 
On insert/update/delete in any features update the count for that audience
{“subscriptions”: 2, “alerts”: 3, “newsletter”: 5}

Case 2: [Using this approach]
This will be calculated at run time and audience_id will be used as a foreign key in the appropriate tables(Subscription/Alert/Newsletter).

title: SCIM Migration
body:
currently DCIM config/ flags are being stored in account_app DB in table account_settings, with attribute 'PEOPELDATA_${VENDOR}_SETTINGS', this needs to be migrated to the new provisioning syncing config table SCIM uses the following object- provision":{"isProvisionSelected":true,"isScimTokenGenerated":true}

in Azure, Okta and OneLogin, this needs to be deleted.

The token for SCIM is stored in identity_mgmt table api_tokens with client as vendor. this client needs to be stored as token ref for SCIM in new config table for existing configs. The new api tokens will be stored as configId as client and same in token ref.

On a SCIM request currently we are validating against vendor constant and allowing the request, we should query the config table validate the configId exists, and SCIM enabled against tokenRef and proceed.

title: Multiple SCIM
body:
We are allowing multiple instances of same vendor, and a Generic SCIM to be configured. We are also extending the SCIM schema to allow simpplr standard and custom fields. The new schemas will be

urn:simpplrapp:<tid>:scim:schemas:extension:User - custom fields

Existing SCIM schema

urn:scim:schemas:core:1.0

urn:scim:schemas:extension:enterprise:1.0

The DB schema, API contracts, Field mappings and Migration strategy is mentioned in underlying documents.

autocomplete: RCA NL Gateway CORS Issue UAT
title: RCA NL Gateway CORS Issue UAT
body:
Issue: NL Api-gateway CORS Configuration Misapplication in UAT Environment

Issue timeline:

Date/Time Reported: 10-Oct--2024 /

Date/Time of fix: 10-Oct-2024 / 8:10 IST

Date/Time when it started to break: 10-Oct-2024 / 5:40 IST

 

Summary: An error occurred during CORS testing when changes intended for the development environment were mistakenly applied to UAT. Attempting to revert the changes did not resolve the issue, resulting in continued challenges.

How was issue fix?
Redeployed the Api-gateway using Terraform to fix the issue.

How it got introduced?:
While testing a CORS issue in the development environment, we made some adjustments to the Terraform configuration. During this process, we intended to update the CORS settings for the development endpoint but accidentally applied the changes to the UAT environment instead. This mistake led to unexpected issues, and reverting the changes did not resolve the problem.

Why it got missed?:

  1. Neither validation was done post-change nor did the dev test to changes done.

Improvements:

  • Remove access to higher environments to prevent accidental changes from being applied.

  • Make sure, the testing will be done after the changes applied.

title: 23.Q3 Sprint Retrospective
body:
Agile retrospective as a whole

 

Start date: End date:

 

  1. Gives an opportunity to all the projects teams to reflect on past work together and identify ways to improve.

  2. Agile teams hold retrospective meetings after a time-boxed period of work is complete

  3. During the retrospective, the team discusses what went well, what did not go as planned, and how to make the next work period better.

Why are agile retrospectives important?

 

  • As per the manifesto the team must reflect on the last sprint work and improve gradually

  • Agile retrospectives put this philosophy into practice — helping to ensure that issues that impede performance or productivity do not go unnoticed or unaddressed.

  • Agile retrospectives are also an opportunity for every voice to be heard.

title: 23.Q2 Retrospective

title: Release Retrospective
body:
Release retrospective is a tool that helps to monitor and improve how a team is performing. The comprehensive retrospective offers a higher-level view of how the team works and is helpful for the team, stakeholders, and higher-ups.

How to get started:

  • Set the stage: Welcome everyone to the meeting, go over the agenda, and introduce any discussion techniques.

  • Gather input: Discuss what happened in the last sprint — considering both high and low points.

  • Brainstorm ideas: Explore ideas for overcoming any known issues. Consider the flip side, too — recognized positive patterns to continue in future sprints.

  • Pick solutions: Choose action items to implement in the next sprint.

  • Close: Recap key points of the agile retrospective, summarized results, and share any notes with the team.

title: Encryption at Rest (EAR)

Simpplr People user creation process

Below is the logic we use to create users and method we use to populate their email when an org has Encryption at Rest turned on.

title: Open Questions On Conversational Search
body:
1. For a case where the follow-up question is answered from the conversation history, plan is to get the answer from there itself.

title: VPC - Network Firewall
body:
AWS Network Firewall, in simple terms, is an additional layer of security to protect your infrastructure against dangerous threats like malware, botnets, and DDoS attacks while getting advanced access control.

With AWS Network Firewall, you can create firewall rules that provide fine-grained control over network traffic and easily deploy firewall security across your VPCs.

What are Network firewall Rule group types?

  1. Stateful rule group: These are like smart rules that understand the context of network traffic. They can allow or block traffic based on things like source, destination, and more. Think of them as traffic cops that can make decisions based on what they see.

  2. Stateless rule group:: These are more like basic traffic filters. They follow simple rules to either allow or block traffic, without understanding the context. It’s like a list of specific traffic rules that are applied without considering the bigger picture.

Steps to setup:

Create a dedicated subnet for the Network Firewall.

Note: A Network Firewall needs a dedicated subnet with a /28

Network Firewall — Rule Groups.

title: Process for reviewing and merging Dependabot PRs
body:
In Github workflow there’s a .dependabot.yml file. That tells dependabot to open PRs for packages that need to be updated

Right now, they all fail the first time (because of an authentication issue with npm packages eg. athena)

We’ve set a limit of only three dependabot PRs at a time

For now we can just do this on adhoc basis when we have time. Can revisit this if it causes a problem

Process

  • Run the build again. Should usually pass

  • If passing, can check it and merge (for now we can agree to merge without reviews for these PRs only)

  • If not can close without merging

Questions

  • Should we have an epic for dealing with the ones that fail?

  • Can we configure github to allow no reviews for dependabot PRs only?

title: Feed Historical Migration performance
body:
Issue

  1. for tenants with large data , feed migration historical data takes a lot of time

  2. 70k records took 6hrs approx to complete

  3. some prod tenants have 150k records. The entire migration should complete within 12 hrs for this tenant.

Solutions

  1. expose bulk produce from common message broker.

  2. use bulk produce to send data to historical outbox.

  3. DE team consumers can handle more traffic

  4. increase CPU and memory for change stream processor service

  5. increase records fetched per iteration

  6. right now historical jobs can be broken down into at least 2 jobs without any change. This supported out of the box .

    1. feed moderation

    2. feed interaction

  7. further break down feed historical ingestion job into many jobs

    1. feed created

    2. comment created

    3. feed reactions

    4. comment reactions

    5. feed fav

    6. feed share

title: Content Translation - Problem Statement
body:
PROBLEM STATEMENT:-

Currently, we lack the ability to publish content in multiple languages with multilingual editing capabilities. Simpplr’s content translation flow relies on Google Translate, which presents several issues:

  • Translations are often inaccurate, particularly for regional languages.

  • There is no option to edit and correct the translated content.

  • Users must manually translate content and publish multiple ‘duplicate’ items.

  • There is a legal requirement in Canada to provide content in both English and French, though this mainly applies to federal regulations.

  • Users cannot easily distinguish between manually translated/verified content and machine-translated content.

  • There is no way to view translated versions of content directly without changing the profile language.

title: Focus
body:
The focus should have an outline and should indicate to the user where the current focus is.
All the interactive elements are by default focusable such as buttons, links and so on.
But incase we want to make sure focus has to move to a particular element then in that can we should use tabindex as 0. But if we provide tab index 0 then we have to provide role to the element such as button. We cannot provide roles like presentation or region with tab index 0. The role should indicate that its a interactive element.
The Focus should always move from left to right.

autocomplete: Odin: Enhanced Recipient Control for Merge Sync/Prov Error Emails
title: Odin: Enhanced Recipient Control for Merge Sync/Prov Error Emails
body:
In the existing setup, all admin users receive error emails related to user syncing and provisioning. The goal is to empower admin users to choose a specific set of recipients for these error emails concerning User Syncing and Provisioning.

We can add a new column (send_sync_prov_email) on the users table in identity_mgmt with boolean value.

This value can be fetched in the v1/identity/usersyncprov/internal/activeAppManagers api.

The value in this column determines whether users should be considered for sending email.

Users will receive emails in all cases except when the value is false.

PS: Given the absence of a current UI for saving the list of admin users for email receipt preferences, we can manually set the value to false for admin users we do not want to receive emails.

Web --> "fileName": "clone_web_handler_%DATE%.log"


[B] After running update_json_handler_log

# For all clone platform handler handler (./update_json_handler_log [CLIENT_NAME])

e.g ./update_json_handler_log Republic

"logPath": "/var/log/socrates/[CLIENT_NAME]" ==> "logPath": "/var/log/socrates/Republic"


[C] Other information

### Logger service

example config

```

{

"log": {

  "fileName": "console_handler_%DATE%.log",

  "maxSize": "50mb",

  "maxFiles": "1d",

  "logPath": "/var/log/socrates/",

  "loggerServicePath":"/core-engine/socrates-assistant/SA_Tools/logger/loggerService"

 }

}

```


- **filename** - File name base on channel.

- **maxSize** - Maximum size of the file after which it will rotate. This can be a number of bytes, or units of kb, mb, and gb. If using the units, add 'k', 'm', or 'g' as the suffix. The units need to directly follow the number. (default: null)

- **maxFiles** - Maximum number of logs to keep. If not set, no logs will be removed. This can be a number of files or number of days. If using days, add 'd' as the suffix. (default: null).

- **logPath** - File path

- **loggerServicePath** - Location Logger Service path


NOTE : After handler or application is running log file will be generate base on logPath

title: How To Install (Mini QA-Bot)
body:
i) create new directory

$ sudo mkdir QAB

ii) give permission

$ sudo chmod -R 777 QAB

iii) copy install.sh file to new directory

$ sudo cp install.sh QAB

iv) copy basecksum.txt file to new directory

$ sudo cp basecksum.txt QAB

v) copy tarball file to new directory

$ sudo cp qabot-v2-business_20181228.tar.gz QAB

vi) copy library file to new directory

$ sudo cp pbar.lib QAB

vii) go to new directory

$ cd QAB

viii) give write permission to install.log

$ sudo chmod 777 .

ix) give executable permission to install.sh

$ sudo chmod 755 install.sh

x) run installation

$ ./install.sh qabot-v2-business_20181228.tar.gz | tee install.log


NOTE :

  • tarball file will usually come in this format qabot-v2-business_yyyymmdd.tar.gz
  • these are important directories you will see after extractions

i) handler

ii) qabot

  • these are important files you will see after extractions

i) package.json

ii) update_handler_id

title: What is Web QA-Bot
body:
QA-Bot V2 web application key development objective is to allow a more organize approach of performing regression testing via a more user-friendly interface. It supports the features that all QA-Bot V2 CLI has currently and additionally it has new capability to perform load testing on Socrates Bot.

Main features:

  1. Execute command Using Web UI

  2. Monitor running process via Web UI

  3. Using new database name 'qabotdb'

  4. Configuration is store in database (no more json files)

  5. Run multiple instance concurrently

  6. Have own unix username ‘qabot’

  7. Store test plan in database

  8. Able to export test plan to local test environment

title: Aisera- Use Cases
body:
As shared with Aisera team:

Development use cases for end-to-end delivery where we need to configure the app as follows:

  1. Controllable and non-controllable feature settings

  2. Change the widget's look and feel to wrap it in Simpplr branding as per the client's current branding

  3. Manage the widget's placement

  4. Additionally, we may consider the opportunity to cross-sell this in the near future.

Other use cases to keep in mind include the following:

  1. The user should not have to log in twice to access the chatbot, and it should support seamless access through SAML/SSO.

  2. The user should receive responses for intranet-related queries with Simpplr data indexing.

  3. User-level access and authentication, as well as role-based access, should be provided.

  4. The user should be able to access the widget using a mobile interface.

  5. Analytics requirements for app-admin performance, especially in the case of Simpplr data indexing.

  6. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

title: API Testing Strategy
body:
Below are the key points which need to be followed for API Testing:

  • API’s will be tested as per the confluence document so confluence document should be up to date before API is assigned to QA for testing.

  • Any deviation from the confluence document will be marked as a BUG by the QA.

  • API sign off will be provided on QA Environment.

  • Decision regarding API Automation is still pending as we need to be sure whether these integrations can be automated or not.

title: Multi-Login LLD for Kita
body:
Assumptions:

  • User ID, email & mobile number will be unique across the application.

New changes:

  • MFA will now be sending a One time password to the email/password they entered in the profile.

  • Security questions will not be present (custom security questions will be removed and security questions against profile will be used instead only for User ID based logins)

User flows:

  • Login Page

    • Support email/mobile/userid

    • First time login (User already provisioned and profile activation pending)

      • Email → send/resend an OTP to email → validate the OTP → Set password → [set security questions] or [MFA flow] → Activate the user → Land on home page

      • Phone → send/resend an OTP to phone → validate the OTP → Set password → [set security questions] or [MFA flow] → Activate the user → Land on home page

      • User ID → Verify security questions against profile attributes → Set password → [set security questions] or [?? MFA flow ??] → Activate the user → Land on home page

      • SSO → complete auth flow → [Provision +] Activate the user → Land on home page

    • Subsequent Login - MFA Disabled

      • Email → Enter password → [MFA Flow] or [set security questions if user hasn’t configured before] → Land on home page

      • Mobile → Enter password → [MFA Flow] or [set security questions if user hasn’t configured before] → Land on home page

      • User ID → Enter password → [MFA Flow] or [set security questions if user hasn’t configured before] → Land on home page

      • SSO → complete auth flow → Land on home page

    • Subsequent Login - MFA Enabled:

      • Email/Mobile → Enter password → MFA via OTP to email/phone → Land on home page

      • Email/Mobile → Enter password → MFA via authenticator → Land on home page

      • User ID → Enter password → MFA via OTP if email/phone was entered (prefer email) → Land on home page

        • OPEN QUESTION: What will be the MFA for User IDs without email or phone?

  • Forgot Password:

    • Email/Phone → Enter email/phone → Verify against Database and sent OTP to email/phone → Enter OTP → Set password → Login page

    • User ID (Email/phone was entered later) → Enter User ID → Verify against Database and send OTP to email/phone → Enter OTP → Set password → Login page

    • User ID (Email/phone not present or not working) → Enter User ID → Verify against security questions on profile attributes → Set password → Login page

    • If security questions are enabled:

      • Email/Phone →

        • Send OTP → Set password → Login page

        • Answer security questions → Set password → Login page

      • User ID:

        • Enter User ID → If email/phone is present as part of profile → Use email/phone → Enter email/phone → Send OTP → Set password → Login page

          • Verify security questions against profile attributes → Set password → Login page

        • Enter User ID → If email/phone is not present as part of profile → Answer security questions → Set password → Login page

        • Enter User ID → Answer security questions → Set password → Login page

    • If security questions are not enabled:

      • Email/Phone → Enter → Send OTP → Set password → Login page

      • User ID

        • If email/phone is present → Send OTP → Set password → Login page

        • Answer security questions → Set password → Login page

  • Provision User

    • One by one

      • Mandate user to set the identifier (email/phone/userid) and capture the details accordingly

      • ?????

      • Deeplink as part of message ????

    • CSV

      • Modify the existing CSV to capture additional details

      • Mandatory field checks will change

      • Content of registration emails won’t include activation links now - since activation will be done during “First Login”

      • Support to send SMS to mobile based users to be added

    • Remote provisioning source

      • Change in flow → Users must now be kept in “Pending Activation” state → First login → User is activated

    • People Tab

      • Allow searching for pending activation users (show status filter)

  • Sync Users

    • Remote syncing source:

      • Even sync users whose current status is “Pending Activation”

      • Matching logic should change → at present, we match against emails

    • CSV:

      • Implement from scratch

    • One by one:

      • Update the APIs

  • Deprovision Users

    • CSV:

      • Implement from scratch

  • Bulk Actions:

    • ?????

  • Notifications

    • Changes in templates

    • Add new templates for SMS

  • MFA

    • We will disable the MFA via authenticator that is implemented now and revisit a need later

    • MFA with OTP will be supported

  • Recover MFA

    • Out of scope for Kita

  7. Every one has a shared understanding of the prioritization of tasks

  8. Proper story description and grooming session before the start of the Sprint

  9. Description of the stories should be clear and any changes / additions to the requirements are specified in the Description section and not in the Comments section

  10. Any change in the requirements are properly communicated to the team

title: Team Bigfoot - Definition of Done
body:
1. All Codacy issues are fixed on PRs

  2. Unit Testing and code coverage should be done properly and avoid doing it later

  3. Proper integration testing, QA testing and code review by peers

  4. Unit Test cases is updated by Developers

  5. Code is refactored and reviewed

  6. Code is ready to be shipped or merged with the main branch

  7. Should fulfil all the acceptance criteria mentioned in the story

  8. Ensure that new feature / development shouldn’t introduce new buys or hamper existing functionality

  9. Every one agrees on the delivery of the final product and no one compromise on the quality of the product

title: Team Atom - Working Agreement
body:
1. Participate and communicate in meetings

  2. Notify team if not able to attend meetings

  3. Attend daily Scrums

  4. Meetings should be timeboxed

  5. Respond to queries in a short period of time

  6. Be on time for all meetings

  7. Stick to agenda in every meeting

title: Team Falcon - Working Agreement
body:
1. Inform team members of upcoming leave - so that the team can plan accordingly

  2. Maintain Slack status when we are away / going on leave and back from leave

  3. Work on priority items first

  4. Respond to meeting invites

  5. Active participation in team meetings

  6. Log time in Jira regularly

  7. Update Jira status regularly

  8. Take ownership and pride in our work

  9. Ask for help

  10. Documentation of new features

  11. Assign task when it is ready to assign to QA / Dev team

  12. Good coordination and communication among team members

  13. Give a heads up on blockers

  14. Take up items which you can complete in a sprint

title: Packaging
body:
Backend

Here are steps to be followed to create Package

  1. Pull latest code from Simpplr2.0 release branch, and run following commands from scripts folder. Commit sfdx_min_js.js and other translation json files as part of this.

    1. gulp buildBackendJs

    2. gulp crowdinUpload

    3. gulp crowdinDownload

  2. Deploy latest code from branch to packaging / patch org. You can use Jenkins job to push latest code to main packaging org.

  3. Login to packaging org, go to Packages > Simpplr > Add any new components (Specially new js files / test classes) and then click upload

  4. We need to pick managed and PostInstallSetup page for post install instructions during package / patch creation

Frontend

Latest code will be getting deployed by Jenkins pipeline in s3://static.simpplr.com/simpplr/unmanaged/release-version folder

  1. Copy above folder contents from s3://static.simpplr.com/simpplr/unmanaged/release-version to s3://static.simpplr.com/simpplr/release-version

  2. In cloudfront, invalidate /simpplr/release-version/* folder contents.

no focus and direction... "Calls are pretty tough, I'm gonna pray for you guys"

"I would say 'reach out to me with any questions' but I really don't mean that"

title: Frontend localization process
body:
There are two gulp tasks created for upload / download translations file in crowdin.

To upload new keys to crowdin for translation, run following command

yarn gulp crowdinUpload

To download translated json file, run following command, this will downloaded localized files in translations directory.

yarn gulp crowdinDownload --release=mastercrowdinDownload

title: Team Chromium - Definition of Done
body:
1. Coding standards should be followed

  2. Work done has been unit tested and test cases have been written

  3. Testing should be completed in QA environment

  4. All tasks and subtasks related to story should be complete

  5. Tickets should be verified by QA

  6. Avoid regression bugs

  7. Pull request has been reviewed and builds without errors

  8. Jira tickets have been appropriately updated

  9. Stories should be implemented, verified and tested within the given timeframe

  10. Integration testing is done

  11. Work done meets acceptance criteria
